qas.question: How many terms does Japanese have for the color green?
What is the Vietnamese word for both blue and green?
What are the colors of traffic lights in Japan?

answers.text: the same colors that other countries have

qas.question: How is 藍 pronounced in Japanese?
How is 綠 pronounced in Sino-Vietnamese?
What Chinese word for green is derived from English?
How many words for green does Thai have?

plausible_answers.text: to be in leaf, to flourish

qas.question: What does Ian mean in reference to trees?

context: In some languages, including old Chinese, Thai, old Japanese, and Vietnamese, the same word can mean either blue or green. The Chinese character 青 (pronounced qīng in Mandarin, <b3_0>ao<b3_0/> in Japanese, and <b4_0>thanh<b4_0/> in Sino-Vietnamese) has a meaning that covers both blue and green; blue and green are traditionally considered shades of "青". In more contemporary terms, they are 藍 (lán, in Mandarin) and 綠 (lǜ, in Mandarin) respectively. Japanese also has <a0_0><b6_0>two<b6_0/><a0_0/> terms that refer specifically to the color green, 緑 (midori, which is derived from the classical Japanese descriptive verb midoru "<b7_0>to be in leaf, to flourish<b7_0/>" in reference to trees) and グリーン (<b5_0>guriin<b5_0/>, which is derived from the English word "green"). However, in Japan, although the traffic lights have <a2_0>the same colors that other countries have<a2_0/>, the green light is described using the same word as for blue, "aoi", because green is considered a shade of aoi; similarly, green variants of certain fruits and vegetables such as green apples, green shiso (as opposed to red apples and red shiso) will be described with the word "aoi". Vietnamese uses a single word for both blue and green, <a1_0>xanh<a1_0/>, with variants such as xanh da trời (azure, lit. "sky blue"), lam (blue), and lục (green; also xanh lá cây, lit. "leaf green").
